Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Discoveries in Multiphase Detonations: Fuel Droplet Processing at Extreme Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Combustion of storable, liquid fuels is common in everyday life, powering cars, trains, airplanes, and ships. The combustion efficiency in these engines depends on the reaction rate. As the reaction rate becomes faster, the combustion front propagates faster and can exceed the speed of sound, in a process known as a detonation wave. Combustion devices operating with detonation waves can yield much higher efficiencies compared to traditional engines. In liquid fueled detonation engines, fuel droplets, about the size of a red blood cell, must be broken up, evaporated, and reacted over few nanoseconds. In this project, a combination of new experimental and simulation methods will be used to better understand liquid fuel break up process and to develop a new model for the burning of fuel droplets in a detonation wave. The model developed can be used to improve the design of engines for civilian and defense applications. <br/><br/>The overall goal of this project is to understand how 2-20 nanometer fuel droplets undergo simultaneous hydrodynamic breakup, vaporization, and reaction (SBVR) under detonation conditions. For this purpose, a new SBVR model will be developed and tested with fully resolved microscale simulations, and mesoscale multiphase detonation tube experiments and simulations. Microscale simulations will be performed using an in-house simulation code, IMPACT, based on the ghost fluid method. The SBVR model will be implemented on Lagrangian point particles in the open source hydrodynamics code, FLASH to simulate mesoscale experiments. Experiments will be conducted using the multiphase detonation tube facility. The key tasks to be conducted include, (i) investigations of simultaneous droplet breakup, phase change, and reaction in microscale simulations; (ii) measurement of detonation properties for various fuel droplet sizes using detonation tube experiments; and (iii) development and testing the SBVR model using experimental and mesoscale simulations data.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed a deeper understanding of combustion in extreme environments. Combustion of liquid fuels is common in everyday life, powering cars, trains, airplanes, and ships. The efficiency of combustion powered engines increases as reactions becomes faster. Detonations represent a mode of combustion traveling at many times the speed of sound. In this environment, liquid fuel droplets must be broken up, evaporated, and reacted nearly simultaneously, over very short time scales. These processes are difficult to capture with our previous models and simulation capabilities and lead to poor simulation predictions, hindering our design and use of high-efficiency detonation engines.

This project developed a new experimental facility and simulation capabilities to provide a deeper understanding of how droplet breakup and react in detonations. First-of-their-kind images of droplet breakup in a detonation were acquired using new laser-based diagnostics. These experiments showed that existing models underpredicted the droplet breakup time leading to inaccurate simulations. High resolution, direct numerical simulations highlighted the role of fluid instability at the droplet surface and the effect of evaporation on breakup. These experimental and simulation results were used to develop an efficient point-particle model, capable of capturing droplet breakup effects in detonations. Simulations using these models highlighted the role of droplet breakup in enabling liquid-fueled detonation. The tuned model allows droplet effects to be capture by simple and efficient computational points representing particles suspended in gases. This method enables accurate system-level simulation of full-scale engines for commercial and military applications.

This work funded the training of three graduate students in areas vital to our national security. These students collaborated with researchers at our Department of Energy (NNSA) and Department of Defense (Navy) laboratories, developing new career opportunities. This project also enabled additional research in detonation engines and hypersonic droplet impacts that will continue to support our national security.
